Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; creamy white slip; interior: glazed black; undetermined pattern with triangles in added white with added red centres between white bands; below, part of crescent pattern; exterior: painted decoration consisting of part of chiton and himation with dotted paryphe of female facing left.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the Aphaia Painter. The painter and the group are named after the chalice found in the sanctuary of Aphaia on Aegina and vessels from this group display a thematic unity. All the vessels describe figures in garments and, in particular, the lower parts of chitons and himatia. None of the vessels in this group have any filling ornament and the interior decoration of some of the vessels consists of komasts rendered in the light on dark technique. Lemos identifies the interior decoration on this sherd as the right leg of a dancing komast. A number of Chian chalices from Emporio (Lemos no. 1468) and Rizari (Lemos no, 1487) depict komast dancers alongside female figures dressed in long chitons and playing the double flute and tambourine (or possibly holding a wreath). Occasionally, the female figure is holding a pomegranate. On some chalices, the female figures are incised whilst on others, they are depicted in outline. The figures on the sherds from Naukratis are likely to be from similar scenes interpreted as dancers following and performing with a chorus of women.
